qas.question: Along with Cirrus, what types of clouds are cold and high?
What color do Cirrus clouds appear in infrared?
Along with Stratus, what clouds are lower and warmer?
What color are Strarus clouds in infrared?
What is the range of the near-infrared channel in micrometers?
Besides cumulonimbus, what types of clouds are lower and warmer?
What ice clouds show up grey in infrared?
What land surface can be a similar temperature to the surrounding land?
What color are lower intermediate clouds on infrared?

plausible_answers.text: the difference in brightness of the IR4 channel (10.3–11.5 µm) and the near-infrared channel (1.58–1.64 µm)

qas.question: What difference allows high clouds to be distinguished?

context: High, cold ice clouds such as <b5_0><b6_0>Cirrus<b5_0/> or <a0_0>Cumulonimbus<b6_0/><a0_0/> show up bright <a1_0>white<a1_0/>, lower warmer clouds such as Stratus or <a2_0>Stratocumulus<a2_0/> show up as <a3_0><b8_0>grey<b8_0/><a3_0/> with intermediate clouds shaded accordingly. <b7_0>Hot land surfaces<b7_0/> will show up as dark-grey or black. One disadvantage of infrared imagery is that low cloud such as stratus or fog can be a similar temperature to the surrounding land or sea surface and does not show up. However, using <b9_0>the difference in brightness of the IR4 channel (10.3–11.5 µm) and the near-infrared channel (<a4_0>1.58–1.64<a4_0/> µm)<b9_0/>, low cloud can be distinguished, producing a fog satellite picture. The main advantage of infrared is that images can be produced at night, allowing a continuous sequence of weather to be studied.
